name: Eat for Eight Bucks: Chili con Frijoles
description: [Photograph: Robin Bellinger] Shopping List 1 onion: $0.50 1 green bell pepper: $1.32 2 serrano peppers: $0.25 1 cup uncooked lentils: $1.00 1/2 cup uncooked beans: $0.25 2 or 3 canned plum tomatoes (pro-rated): $1.00 Cilantro (pro-rated): $0.50 1 cup...
recipeIngredient: 1 medium onion, peeled and finely chopped
3 garlic cloves, peeled and finely chopped
1/2 large green bell pepper, seeds removed and finely chopped
1/2 to 2 small, fresh hot green chiles, finely chopped, seeds removed for a milder chili (I used 2 serranos and most of their seeds)
1 cup uncooked lentils, picked over and washed
2 to 3 canned plum tomatoes, drained and finely chopped (I used about 1/4 of a 28-ounce box of chopped tomatoes)
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro leaves, plus a little extra for garnish
To serve: millet (or rice or tortilla chips), 1/4 cup plain yogurt or sour cream (optional), 2 ounces grated cheese (such as cheddar or pepper jack, optional)

recipeInstructions.text: Put the oil in a medium pan over a medium-high flame. When hot, add the onion, garlic, green pepper, and hot green chiles. Stir and fry for about 3 minutes, or until the seasonings just start to brown. Do let them start to get some color, even if it takes 6 minutes or 10. Turn down the heat to medium-low and continue to sauté for another 3 minutes. Now add the cumin, paprika, thyme, sage, oregano, and cayenne. Stir briskly once or twice and add the lentils, 4 cups of water, the beans, tomatoes, chopped cilantro, and salt. Bring to a boil. Cover, turn the heat down to low, and cook gently for 50 minutes.
Mix the cornmeal with 3 tablespoons water and then pour the mixture into the chili pot. Stir to mix and bring to a simmer. Cover and simmer gently for 10 minutes, stirring now and then.
Serve with millet (or rice or tortilla chips), topping each bowl with a tablespoon of yogurt and a sprinkle of cheese and cilantro.
